titleInfo.title: Anti-Inflammatory Effect of H2S on Atherosclerosis and Erectile Function

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.abstract: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve and maintain an erectile penis capable of adequate sexual intercourse; it affects more than half of men over the age of 45. Atherosclerosis, a cardiovascular disease that involves the build-up of fat, cholesterol, inflammatory materials, and other debris in the blood vessels, is one of the major causes of erectile dysfunction, as it affects the blood flow to the penis. Hydrogen sulfide is a vasodilator with the ability to improve blood flow. PURPOSE: In the current study, we investigated the potential protective effect of hydrogen sulfide against atherosclerosis and erectile dysfunction. METHODS: Male ApoE knockout mice were randomly divided into three groups: ApoE Knockout mice (ApoE-/-) fed a standard diet, ApoE knockout mice fed an atherogenic diet, and ApoE-/- fed an atherogenic diet with SG1002, a Hydrogen sulfide releasing a prodrug. A fourth group of ApoE and Cystathionine ÔÅß lyase (CSE) double knockout mice (ApoE-/-/CSE-/-) fed an atherogenic diet was added. All the mice were fed a standard diet with water ad libitum until eight weeks, when groups 2 and 4 were switched to an atherogenic diet, and group 3 was switched to an atherogenic diet with SG1002 for eight weeks. All the mice were sacrificed, and experiments were done subsequently. Vascular functional studies were assessed using wire myography experiments, and the cytokines in both the Serum and CC were measured using Luminex cytokine assays and western blot. RESULTS: There was an increased contraction and reduced endothelium-dependent, endothelium-independent, and NANC-mediated relaxation in the internal pudendal artery (IPA) and corpus cavernosum (CC) of ApoE-/-/CSE-/- mice. Treatment with SG1002 enhanced parasympathetic effects and reduced sympathetic effects in ApoE-/- mice fed an atherogenic diet. Additionally, CSE deletion led to elevated levels of p-ERK, ASC/TMS1, and cleaved GSDMD, which are responsible for inflammation in the CC. CONCLUSION: CSE deficiency led to endothelial dysfunction, while CSE protected against inflammation following atherosclerotic stimuli via the ERK/NLRP3/GSDMD pathway.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Atherosclerosis, Corpus Cavernosum, Erectile Dysfunction, Hydrogen sulfide, Internal Pudendal Artery, SG1002
Justin La Favor, Professor Directing Dissertation; Zhibin Yu, University Representative; Gloria Salazar, Committee Member; Michelle Parvatiyar, Committee Member.
